Trying to randomly vary my initial guesses for an optimization to in a way prove that this is the global minima. I have what I think is the global minima. Everything about it is nice, it makes sense in the domain that it's in, and has great confidence intervals.

I have the range where I know the parameters I pass in are realistic.

I'm thinking of having it get optimized, randomly nudged by a certain % and so on and so forth over a certain amount of times all wrapped up in a for loop. Something like this :
```pert = 0.20
IG = IG.*(1 .+ (.- pert .+ 2 .* pert .* rand(-0.5:1e-5:0.5, length(IG))))```
My other idea is to generate all the combinations using the range that I know for each parameter, select a specific amount and have something randomly pick out of those combinations to pass in and optimize the problem.

Any other suggestions would be greatly be appreciated

If you can't do rigerious global optimization then you are in the field of heuristic global optimization.
So pick your fav from there like particle swarm optimizers, simulated annealing, Bayes Opt etc.

If its differentiable, then you can use gradient descent, lbgfs, quasinewton methods etc with random restarting.

But these don't yield proofs

text: Only thing I can see is that starting with a very small box around the solution will allow to get rid of some of the candidate boxes faster. There may be some fancy trick by bounding the derivatives too.

text: As for dimension 5, it really dependent on your problem and how small you want your box with guarantee global minima to be. The complexity is (if I'm not mistaken) something like `O(N^d)` where `N` is the number of bisection you need in each dimension and `d`  is the dimension. So if you can get away with around 10 bisections it may be manageable, if you need 50 it may already start to grow out of hand
